results.title: Daughters of the dust [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: American Playhouse Theatrical Films, WMG, Geechee Girls Production and Julie Dash
results.brief_description: At the turn of the century the Peazant family, a multigenerational community threatened with break-up, gathers for a reunion on an island off the coast of South Carolina, historically a place of entry for the European slave ships and a haven for self-emancipated Africans and indigenous peoples. Structured around the twin narratives of Nana, born into slavery, and that of the Unborn Child, this is a rites-of-passage story invoking Islam, Christianity and West African spiritual customs. It is not narrative-driven in the Western mode but is balletic, operatic, non-linear and based on the African oral tradition of the Griot (story-teller), drawing on the Gullah dialect. Dash was also inspired by the literature of African-American women writers. Cast includes Adisa Anderson, Cora Lee Day, Alva Rogers, Barbara-0 and Trula Hoosier.

results.title: Daughters of darkness = The Promise of red lips = The Red lips = Le Rouge aux levres
results.creator_credit: Showking Films, Maya Films, Henry Lange, Paul Collet and Harry Kumel
results.brief_description: In the lost space of an opulent Ostend hotel, eerily deserted in the off season, a young but hardly innocent couple on their honeymoon encounter the apparently ageless, sunlight-fearing, lesbian Countess Bathory. Kumel imaginatively balances the erotic malaise and violence of vampire folklore and a European (specifically Belgian) surrealist tradition with thirties Hollywood camp and comic strip tableaux. Perverse sexuality is located in a setting of decadent highlife which seems to immobilise the “victims”. Originally titled “La Rogue aux Levres” (Lips of Blood). Cast includes John Karlen, Delphine Seyrig, Danielle Ouimet and Andrea Rau.

results.title: Dating the enemy
results.creator_credit: Total Films, Sue Milliken and Megan Simpson
results.brief_description: Guy Pearce and Claudia Karvan star in this comedy which looks at the battle between the sexes from a new perspective. Brett and Tash fall in love but when a lack of compromise threatens their relationship, the forces of the universe intervene. One day they awake to find themselves prisoners in each other’s bodies. Brett learns that being a woman, particularly Tash, presents its own challenges, while Tash learns more than she had bargained for about the male psyche.

results.title: Darling
results.creator_credit: Embassy Pictures Corporation (US), Joseph Janni and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description: Julie Christie won an Academy Award for her performance as an ambitious young model who uses all her assets to achieve social successs. Ultimately, she finds that the life to which she aspired is meaningless and empty. Her relationships with journalist Dirk Bogarde, company director Laurence Harvey, an effeminate photographer and an Italian Prince are never really satisfying. “Darling” was groundbreaking in its time because it exposed the “swinging 60’s” with its more “modern” attitudes towards sexuality, homosexuality and infidelity in a frank and adult manner. The viewer may be left feeling that Christie’s character is shallow and cold despite her vulnerabilty, and that the emptiness of her life is of her own making.

results.title: Dark victory
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, First National Pictures and Edmund Goulding
results.brief_description: Dark victory was nominated for three Oscars in 1940 including Best Picture and Best Actress for Bette Davis. Davis and the film lost out in that year on both counts to “Gone with the wind”. In “Dark victory” Davis plays Judith Traherne, a beautiful young Long Island socialite, without a care in the world until she discovers she is suffering from a potentially fatal brain tumour. Her surgeon offers temporary hope with an operation prolonging her life and simultaneously brings love to Traherne’s life for the first time. One of four collaborations between director and star, “Dark victory” is a typical Hollywood melodrama of the 30s that rises above the ordinary, thanks to the compelling presence of Davis. Davis portrays Traherne as a beguiling, earnest, and impetuous woman, reluctantly facing her own mortality. Humphrey Bogart stars as an Irish horse trainer holding a candle for Traherne’s affection. Future president of the United States Ronald Reagan has a minor role in the film as a playboy socialite. “Dark victory” is reflective of the strong period that Bette Davis’ career was at in the late 1930s and 40s when she enjoyed studio backing and public acclaim.

results.title: Dark star
results.creator_credit: Jack H. Harris and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: Set in the 21st Century, and influenced by ‘Dr. Strangelove’ and ‘2001: a space odyssey’, “Dark Star” is essentially a serious concept about the condition of humankind. Entertaining and exciting, it also has dry humour and special effects that are out of this world. The scoutship Dark Star travels far in advance of the colony ships, combing the universe for unstable planets which could menace the main fleet. The crew of four men has been in space for twenty years, they must remain in space until all their bombs are gone and their mission is complete. Stars Brian Narelle, Dre Pahich, Cal Kuniholm and Dan O’Bannon.

results.title: Dark passage
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, First National Pictures, Jerry Wald and Delmer Daves
results.brief_description: Vincent Parry’s been framed! Wrongly convicted of murdering his wife, Parry (Bogart) busts out of San Quentin and heads for San Francisco, determined to clear himself. Once there, he takes shelter with Irene Jansen (Bacall), a young woman who believes his story and wants to help. Undergoing extensive plastic surgery, Parry drastically changes his appearance, but not his mission. Hidden by his new face, he evades blackmailer’s double-crossers and the cops in a final, desperate effort to find the real killer… before the killer finds him.

results.title: Dark lullabies
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Kathleen Shannon, Irene Angelico, Abbey Jack Neidik, Edward Le Lorrain and Bonnie Sherr Klein
results.brief_description: They are the children of survivors and of perpetrators of the Holocaust. Polarised as their heritage is, many of this generation share a legacy of silence. Canadian filmmaker Irene Angelico, herself a child of concentration camp survivors, undertakes a deeply personal journey; she asks what happened and why? This powerful documentary is structured around the filmmaker’s quest. Having grown up in the shadow of the Holocaust, she searches for comprehension through interviews with survivors and their children in Montreal and in Israel. Despite her own reluctance, her journey inevitably takes her to Germany. Rare interviews show a range of voices among her German contemporaries. Some are as compelled as she to pierce the silence, while others retreat into prejudice and denial. The film offers no easy answers. (Awards: Mannheim, New York, Tokyo)

results.title: Dark habits = entre tinieblas
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Tesauro S A, Luis Calvo and Pedro Almodovar
results.brief_description: Prepare to meet some nuns like you’ve never met before. Junkie nightclub singer Yolanda Bell (Christina S Pascual), takes refuge with the religious order ‘the humble redeemers’, after her boyfriend overdoses on heroin and Yolanda’s on the run from the police. ‘The humble redeemers’ are a good hearted group, trying to save girls from leading a wild life. They do however have a dark side to their operations; dealing drugs, dabbling in pornography and active chain smoking admirers of Cecil Barton. Together they are planning a party to celebrate Mother Superior’s name day; it will be a party to end all parties. Described as an evil twin of films such as ‘Sister act’ and ‘The Sound of music’, this film is Almodovar at his devilish and controversial best. Cast includes Julieta Serrano, Julia Marisa Paredes and Mary Carrillo. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Dark days [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wide Angle Pictures, Palm Pictures, Picture Farm and Marc Singer
results.brief_description: In “Dark days”, first-time filmmaker Marc Singer has documented the lives of the tunnel-dwellers living in deserted segments of New York’s subway network. Shot in stark black and white and illuminated by a single spotlight, we follow the journey of these dignified and articulate characters from the homeless drudgery of the tunnel to public housing above the ground, which offers some hope for the future. Along the way they strive to overcome drug addiction, rat infestation, and chronic destitution, not to mention tension in their relationships with fellow inhabitants; all while maintaining a strength which shatters society’s myths of homelessness. The tunnel- dwellers acted not only as the subjects for this documentary, but also producers and crewmembers, fighting for their voice to be heard and their story to be told. Featuring a soundtrack by DJ Shadow, “Dark days” is a moving and very human portrayal of life in the bowels of the western world.
